chapter.title: Commands Summary
chapter.para: This chapter is to serve as a summary of the basic commands that are implemented in the TDF operating system. For a more detailed description of the commands, please refer to the Detailed Commands Information chapter in this manual, or employ the "help" command in the operating system environment.

section.title: date
section.para: Displays the system date. When given an optional -s option followed by a valid date string in the format YYYYMMDD, the date will be set to the specified date.

section.title: display
section.para: Displays the contents of the current working directory, which is all of the files with an extension of .MPX. Optionally accepts a relative or absolute directory path to function on.

section.title: exit
section.para: The exit command will terminate the MPX operating system. There are no additional arguments that may be passed to this command. This is the safest way to end your MPX session. You will be prompted for confirmation before you are dropped.

section.title: help
section.para: The help command will print out a list of commands and a brief description of each. This is a very useful command to those unfamiliar with the system. For help on a specific command, simple type the name of the command you would like help with as the argument.

section.title: history
section.para: The history command will print out a list of the user's previous commands.

section.title: presume
section.para: The presume command returns a process from the suspended state. To return a process from the suspended state to the ready state run presume with the name of the process as the argument.

section.title: psetprio
section.para: The psetprio command is used to set the priority of a process. The priority must be within the -128 to 127 or an error will be returned. To set the priority of a process run psetprio with an argument -n for the name of the process and argument -p for the priority.

section.title: pshow
section.para: The pshow command displays pertinent information about a particular process. To display information for a process run pshow with the name of the desired process as the argument.

section.title: pshowall
section.para: The pshowall command displays information on all of the current processes regardless of their states. To display information on all current processes run pshowall with no arguments.

section.title: pshowblk
section.para: The pshowblk command displays information on all processes currently in the blocked state. To display information on all currently blocked processes run pshowblk with no arguments.

section.title: pshowrd
section.para: The pshowrd command displays information on all processes currently in in the ready state. To display information on all currently ready processes run pshowrd with no arguments.

section.title: psuspend
section.para: The psuspend command places a process in the suspended state. To place a process in the suspended state run psuspend with the name of the process as the argument.

section.title: version
section.para: The version command will print out the current version, including the version number, date of release, and the first several digits of the subversion commit, which is the source control for tours de force.
